explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Complete small-bowel obstruction (SBO) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with previous abdominal surgery presenting with a history of abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. Obstruction of the small bowel occurs from partial or complete blockage of the small bowel lumen and typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Partial SBO allows a degree of continued flatus with diminished stooling, and complete SBO will result in obstipation (no passage of stool or flatus). SBO has many potential etiologies, although the most common are post-surgical peritoneal adhesions and hernias. On physical examination, SBO typically presents with abdominal tenderness, distention, tympany to percussion, and borborygmi (high-pitched, hyperactive bowel sounds). Potential complications of SBO include bowel rupture and/or necrosis, which can result in sudden-onset peritonitic abdominal signs such as rebound tenderness and guarding. Abdominal x-rays typically demonstrate multiple air-fluid levels in the setting of dilated small bowel loops. Management requires bowel rest and intravenous hydration followed by surgical intervention if the obstruction does not autoreduce. Partial SBO may resolve with monitoring, supportive care, and bowel rest, whereas complete obstruction or any complicated partial obstruction generally requires management through exploratory laparotomy. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Acute cholecystitis (Choice A) presents with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant, often in a patient with a history of gallstones. It would be unlikely to result in small bowel obstruction unless it was complicated by the formation of a cholecystoduodenal fistula leading to gallstone ileus. Colon cancer (Choice B) most commonly occurs in the rectosigmoid region of the large bowel. Lesions within the ascending colon, by convention, typically result in an exophytic mass and slow bleeding resulting in iron deficiency anemia. Cancers within the descending and rectosigmoid colon are more likely to be infiltrative, resulting in partial obstruction of the large bowel. Colon cancer is unlikely to result in complete obstruction. lieus secondary to renal failure (Choice D) is less likely for this patient given her normal urea nitrogen, sodium, and potassium concentrations. lieus refers to intestinal hypomotility without a mechanical obstruction, most commonly occurring following surgery or in the setting of electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., end-stage kidney disease resulting in hyperkalemia), and typically presents with diffuse small and large bowel dilatation. A perforated viscus (Choice E) typically presents with acute-onset diffuse abdominal pain, with findings of abdominal rigidity, rebound tenderness, and guarding on physical examination ('peritoneal signs'). X-rays may demonstrate evidence of pneumoperitoneum, preferably obtained in an erect or left lateral decubitus position. Emergent surgical laparotomy is required for diagnosis and management of the underlying etiology. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 44 of 50 'I 44 . A 25-year-old construction worker has had fever and a painful , swollen right hand for 2 days . His temperature is 39 °C (102 .2°F) . The dorsum of the hand is swollen , erythematous , and tender; there is a small traumatic laceration on the dorsum of the hand with a beefy-red expanding margin and red streaks extending up the arm . The axillary lymph nodes are palpable and tender . Which of the following is the most likely pathogen? A) Bacteroides fragilis F) Enterococcus faecalis B) Clostridium difficile G) Escherichia coli C) Clostridium perfringens H) Staphylococcus epidermidis D) Clostridium tetani I) Streptococcus pneumoniae E) Enterobacter cloacae J) Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) J. Correct Answer: Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A) and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common causes of bacterial lymphadenitis. Cutaneous erythema and swelling at a site of inoculation, with streaking along lymphatic drainage territories and associated tender lymphadenopathy is characteristic of lymphadenitis. Bartonella henselae is another bacterial cause of lymphadenitis related to cat scratches ('Cat scratch disease'), although given the patient's injury secondary to a construction-related laceration, Streptococcus pyogenes lymphadenitis is more likely.

distractor_explanations.A: Bacteroides fragilis is a normal component of the gastrointestinal microbiota. It only results in infections when displaced from the colon such as following surgery or trauma where it has the potential to cause bacteremia, intra-abdominal infections, peritonitis, and subcutaneous abscesses. Clostridium difficile (Choice B) is an opportunistic infection that most commonly occurs following antibiotic alterations of the colonic microbiome. It can present with watery or bloody diarrhea depending on the severity of the infection. Clostridium perfringens (Choice C) can result in myonecrosis (gas gangrene) following traumatic injury. Its spores can also survive in undercooked food, and if ingested, can result in food poisoning. Clostridium tetani (Choice D) is the bacterial cause of tetanus, resulting in the development of spastic paralysis following inoculation via a penetrating traumatic wound. Enterobacter cloacae (Choice E) is a gram-negative rod that can result in a variety of diseases such as urinary tract infection, pneumonia, skin and soft-tissue infections, endocarditis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, ophthalmic infections, and bacteremia. It is not a common cause of lymphadenitis. Enterococcus faecalis (Choice F) is found in normal colonic flora but may result in urinary or biliary tract infections, or subacute endocarditis following gastrointestinal or genitourinary invasive procedures. Escherichia coli (Choice G) is a gram-negative rod with multiple strains presenting with different clinical symptoms. These range from the watery diarrhea of enterotoxigenic E. coli to bloody diarrhea and dysentery in enteroinvasive and enterohemorrhagic E. coli. Additionally, E. coli is a common cause of urinary tract infections such as cystitis and pyelonephritis. Staphylococcus epidermidis (Choice H) is a normal flora of the skin and nose. It can be associated with intravascular catheter and joint prosthesis infections. Streptococcus pneumoniae (Choice I) is a gram-positive diplococcus associated with otitis media, pneumonia, sinusitis, and meningitis. It does not typically cause lymphadenitis. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 45 of 50 'I 45 . A 63-year-old man has had dysphagia and chest pain during meals for 4 months . He has a 6-year history of gastroesophageal reflux . He has limited his intake to liquids for 3 weeks because he regurgitates solid food . Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms? A) Disordered neuromuscular transmission in the esophagus B) Disordered neuromuscular transmission in the oropharynx C) Failure of oropharyngeal propulsion D) Paraesophageal hiatal hernia E) Stricture of the distal esoi:ihagus Correct Answer: E. A stricture of the distal esophagus is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. The patient presents with chronic solid-food dysphagia and chest pain following multiple years of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERO). Chronic GERO, especially if under-managed, raises the risk for development of a distal esophageal stricture. The chronic exposure of the distal esophagus to reflux of gastric acid results in recurrent inflammation leading to potential fibrosis and strictures. Esophageal strictures characteristically present with solid-food dysphagia and regurgitation since the decreased esophageal luminal diameter impedes the passage of solid foods worse than liquid foods. Chronic GERO increases the patient's risk for development of Barrett esophagus (intestinal metaplasia) and esophageal adenocarcinoma, which should be considered in the patient's management and diagnostic evaluation. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Disordered neuromuscular transmission in the esophagus (Choice A) refers to achalasia, which is a type of esophageal dysmotility disorder resulting from deficient peristalsis along the length of the esophagus and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. It manifests as dysphagia to both solids and liquids, odynophagia, weight loss, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food. It is diagnosed through a barium swallow plus esophageal manometry. Disordered neuromuscular transmission in the oropharynx (Choice B) and failure of oropharyngeal propulsion (Choice C) typically occur from impaired cranial nerve function. Oropharyngeal motility is dictated by the coordinated movement of several muscles (e.g., palate, tongue, pharynx), which are primarily innervated by the facial nerve, glossopharyngeal nerve, vagus nerve, and hypoglossal nerve. Underlying neurologic dysfunction (e.g., stroke) can result in incoordination of the oropharyngeal muscles, which can present as transfer dysphagia related to difficulty propelling the food bolus from the oropharynx to the hypopharynx and esophagus. Paraesophageal hiatal hernia (Choice D) results from protrusion of the gastric fundus through the esophageal diaphragmatic hiatus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in its normal location. This can result in obstructive symptoms as the herniated gastric fundus exerts mass effect on the adjacent distal esophagus. The patient demonstrates risk factors for a reflux-associated distal esophageal stricture, which is more common. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 46 of 50 'I 46 . A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent increasingly severe left-sided chest pain for 1 month . He works as an industrial engineer . Examination shows absent breath sounds and dullness to percussion over the lower portion of the left hemithorax . An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion with an extensive peripheral soft-tissue density . Thoracentesis shows a bloody, exudative effusion ; cultures are negative . Cytology of pleural fluid shows malignant cells of uncertain type . An open biopsy specimen shows a dimorphic picture ; there are areas of spindle cells with numerous mitotic figures and areas of cuboidal epithelial cells . Exposure to which of the following agents is the most likely cause of his condition? A) Asbestos B) Nickel C) Talc D) Tobacco E) Toluene diisocyanate Correct Answer: A. Asbestos exposure commonly occurs in the setting of roofing, plumbing, and shipbuilding. It increases the risk for pulmonary asbestosis, characterized by the development of pleural calcified plaques and potential lower-lobe-predominant interstitial fibrotic changes. It also increases the risk for the development of bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma. The patient presents with a left-sided pleural effusion with extensive peripheral soft-tissue density and cytology of the pleural fluid demonstrating malignant cells. Biopsy shows spindle cells with numerous mitotic figures. This presentation and associated x-ray and pathologic findings are typical for pleural mesothelioma. Mesothelioma often presents with pleural soft-tissue thickening and an exudative, often hemorrhagic, pleural effusion. Asbestos exposure is the main risk factor for mesothelioma, while smoking tobacco is not an associated risk factor. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E.
distractor_explanations.B: Nickel exposure is a common cause of contact dermatitis, which is a T-lymphocyte mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction that results in an erythematous, pruritic rash in the location of exposure.
distractor_explanations.C: Infarction of the skin can occur in the setting of protein C or S deficiency after the administration of warfarin. During the initiation of warfarin, the potential for a hypercoagulable state exists, especially in patients with protein C or S deficiency. This can result in warfarin-associated skin necrosis characterized by patches of necrotic skin, not ulcerations.
distractor_explanations.D: Necrobiosis lipoidica is a rare dermatologic condition that often affects the shins. It is a chronic granulomatous skin disease that is associated with diabetes mellitus. It typically presents with reddish or violaceous papules that progress to yellow-brown telangiectatic plaques. Ulceration of the lesions can occur. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 50 of 50

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Adhesions are the most common cause of small bowel obstruction (SBO) in patients with a prior history of intra-abdominal surgery. Obstruction of the small bowel occurs from partial or complete blockage of the small bowel lumen and typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Partial SBO allows a degree of continued flatus with diminished stooling, and complete SBO will result in obstipation (no passage of stool or flatus). SBO has many potential etiologies, with peritoneal adhesions that form following a

distractor_explanations.B: is a microvascular complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus that typically presents in a 'stocking and glove' distribution of the hands and feet. If associated neuropathy of the autonomic nervous system occurs, this can result in complications such as diabetic gastroparesis or dysautonomia. Gastroparesis typically presents with slowly progressive early satiety, nausea, vomiting of undigested food, and abdominal bloating with a succussion splash heard during physical examination. Inguinal hernias (
distractor_explanations.C: are protrusions of abdominal contents into the inguinal region through a defect in the lower abdominal wall. Incarceration and strangulation are potential complications of inguinal hernias and may require surgical correction. Hernias are the second most common cause of SBO in patients with a prior history of intra-abdominal surgery. Mesenteric ischemia (
distractor_explanations.D: can occur in acute and chronic forms. Acute mesenteric ischemic typically occurs from a critical decrease in intestinal blood flow, most commonly from thromboembolic occlusion of a mesenteric vessel (e.g., superior mesenteric artery) or a severe hypoperfusion state (e.g., hemorrhagic shock). This results in ischemia and potential necrosis of the bowel, which presents with abdominal pain out of proportion to the physical examination findings. Sigmoid volvulus (
distractor_explanations.E: results from twisting of the sigmoid mesentery, which can lead to large bowel obstruction and potential rupture or necrosis if not treated. It typically demonstrates a coffee-bean appeara

vignette.presentation:
1. During transfusion of a second unit of crossmatched packed red blood cells , a 62-year-old man has the sudden onset of fever , chills , and mild shortness of breath . Transfusion of the first unit was completed 1 hour ago . Yesterday,
he underwent a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer. His temperature is 38.4 °C (101 .1° F), pulse is 90/min , and blood pressure is 126/77 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation . The remainder of the examination shows no
abnormalities . A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative . Urinalysis shows no hemoglobin . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. Patients may report dark urine or light, pale stools. Many persons have no risk factors; however, those with a history of cirrhosis, sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B or C, liver fluke infection, and ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk. Diagnosis occurs through imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, which may disclose a variety of findings from bile duct wall thickening, a focal mass, or only dilation of bile ducts proximal to the presumed lesion location. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows for the potential direct visualization of the lesion location, bile duct scrapings or biopsy for definitive diagnosis, and stenting of any associated occlusion. Laboratory analysis typically discloses obstructive (direct) hyperbilirubinemia and increased alkaline phosphatase activity. Treatment includes surgical resection and chemotherapy; however, the condition is often late-stage or terminal at the time of diagnosis. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration (Choice A) is sometimes increased in cholangiocarcinoma; however, it is nonspecific and is also increased in colorectal carcinoma along with other various malignancies. It may be followed during treatment to assess treatment response but does not have a specific role in diagnosis. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) (Choice C) evaluates the patency of the hepatobiliary tree and gallbladder. It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. Liver biopsy (Choice D) is useful in the diagnosis of conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, though cholangiocarcinoma is generally small and confined to the biliary tree. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
3. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the anterior neck 30 minutes ago . Examination shows a large , pulsatile hematoma at the level of the thyroid cartilage . As the physician watches ,
the hematoma expands . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Esophagoscopy to rule out esophageal injury

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The initial evaluation of a critically ill patient includes assessing the airway, breathing, circulation, central nervous system, and any external threats to morbidity or mortality. The initial airway assessment determines whether the patient is at risk for compromise to the pathway of airflow from the external environment into the lungs. Examples of airway compromise include structural lesions (angioedema, facial or neck trauma, airway foreign bodies, expanding neck hematomas), space-filling lesions (pharyngeal, laryngeal, tracheal, or bronchial hemorrhage), uncontrolled emesis, or loss of airway protective reflexes (altered mental status). Airway management requires immediate priority whenever a compromising lesion is detected, and an expanding neck hematoma under arterial pressure (pulsatile) may threaten the pathway of airflow within minutes. Endotracheal intubation is the best next step to ensure an intact pathway for air exchange.

distractor_explanations.A: Esophagoscopy to rule out esophageal injury may be necessary in the evaluation of a penetrating neck trauma; however, it should follow emergent management of the airway, breathing, and circulation, as it is a less immediate threat.
distractor_explanations.C: Arteriography may be indicated to assess damage to the carotid arteries or their branches; however, in an unstable patient with an expanding, pulsatile neck hematoma, securing the airway and empirically controlling bleeding are earlier priorities. Additionally, zone two neck injuries are generally managed by direct exploration, whereas zone one and zone three injuries are managed first with vessel imaging before operative exploration.
distractor_explanations.D: Cricothyroidotomy and tracheostomy (Choice E) may be indicated in cases of airway compromise in which endotracheal intubation is unsuccessful. However, in cases of an expanding, arterial neck hematoma, these maneuvers may be difficult or impossible depending on the location of the hematoma. Additionally, inadvertent decompression of an arterial hematoma in the neck may result in exsanguination along with additional airway compromise via hemorrhage into the newly created ostomy. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 4 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
4. A 57-year-old woman has had pain of the left groin and distal anterior thigh with weight bearing for 3 months . She has difficulty bending forward and tying her left shoe . She walks with a mild limp favoring her left lower extremity.
Internal rotation of the left hip produces pain. There is no tenderness over the lateral thigh . Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Osteoarthritis is a noninflammatory arthropathy that occurs secondary to deterioration of articular cartilage. It typically occurs in older persons and may affect any joint. It is commonly associated with the fingers and wrists because of repetitive use, and the hips and knees because of chronic weight bearing, especially in persons with obesity. It is not associated with infectious or inflammatory symptoms and is generally insidious in onset. Patients typically report chronic pain in a joint that is worse with movement or exertion and is improved with rest, often with limited range of motion in a joint because of underlying joint space narrowing and associated pain. Fever, chills, erythema over a joint, traumatic injury, or extra-articular manifestations (e.g., rashes, uveitis, urethritis) suggest an alternate, inflammatory, or infectious cause. Imaging may demonstrate osteophytosis, subchondral cystic or sclerotic changes, and space narrowing of joints. Arthrocentesis typically demonstrates leukocytes of less than 2,000/mm 3 with no additional abnormalities. Treatment includes rest, physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, intra-articular injections (e.g., cortisone), and joint replacement surgery for severe or refractory cases.

distractor_explanations.A: Lumbar radiculopathy presents with pain that radiates down the leg along a specific dermatome secondary to impingement or stretching of a lumbar nerve root, and it often results from underlying degenerative changes of the lumbar spine. It is classically worse with a straight-leg raise maneuver, which stretches the lumbar root and elicits radicular pain, often described as "shooting down the leg." Osteoarthritis of the knee (Choice C) is common in older persons and those with obesity. Pain with osteoarthritis of the knee classically occurs in the knee joint itself and would be unlikely to radiate to the groin or thigh. It may also be associated with knee joint instability. Rheumatoid arthritis of the hip (Choice D) typically is worse in the morning (after a period of rest) with prolonged joint stiffness and improves with use. Extra-articular manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis may also be present such as rheumatoid nodules, pulmonary fibrosis, vasculitis, Sjogren syndrome, and dermatologic manifestations. Trochanteric bursitis (Choice E) presents with localized pain and swelling, often with overlying erythema in the area of the affected bursa. A common risk factor is prolonged pressure applied to the bursa. The associated pain generally does not radiate. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 5 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
5. A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination . She recently tested positive for the BRCA 1 mutation . She wishes to discuss treatment options . She has no history of serious illness and takes no
medications . Her mother and a sister were diagnosed with breast cancer at the ages of 39 and 43 years , respectively . Another sister was diagnosed with breast and ovarian cancer at the age of 35 years . Examination and
mammography of the patient show no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to decrease this patient's risk for developing a BRCA-associated cancer?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management to decrease this patient's risk for developing a BRCA-associated cancer?

choices.text: Tamoxifen therapy and bilateral mastectomy and oophorectomy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: BRCA 1, a hereditary tumor suppressor gene, is highly associated with the development of breast and ovarian malignancies when it is nonfunctional, suppressed, or subfunctional. BRCA 1 expression is low in the majority of high-grade, ductal breast and epithelial ovarian cancers. BRCA 1 plays an important role in the repair of double-stranded DNA breaks, and absent or low-expression of this protein promotes mutations which may eventually lead to malignancy. In families with a strong history of early breast and/or ovarian malignancy, with a known BRCA 1 mutation, the risk for breast or ovarian cancer in women can be decreased through a bilateral mastectomy and oophorectomy.

distractor_explanations.B: Tamoxifen therapy and bilateral mastectomy and tamoxifen therapy and bilateral oophorectomy (Choice D) would limit the patient's risk for either breast cancer or ovarian cancer, respectively, but would still present an increased risk for additional BRCA-associated cancers. Tamoxifen has been shown to reduce the risk for developing breast cancer, but to a lesser extent than prophylactic mastectomy. Tamoxifen therapy and bilateral mastectomy and oophorectomy (Choice C) would not offer additional preventive benefit as compared to isolated surgical removal, as once the organs are no longer present, the risk for malignancy is minimized provided a complete resection occurred. Tamoxifen therapy only (Choice E) may reduce the risk for breast cancer but has been hypothesized to increase the risk for ovarian cancer through the development of ovarian cysts. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 6 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
6. A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the acute onset of a severe diffuse headache . She has vomited once . She is stuporous and responds to vigorous stimulation . There is marked nuchal
rigidity . Babinski sign is present bilaterally . A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a hyperintense signal within the basal cisterns and sulci. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute cerebral infarction J) lntracerebral hemorrhage
Carotid cavernous fistula Mycobacterium avium-intracel/ulare granuloma
Carotid cavernous fistula N) Mycobacterium avium-intracel/ulare granuloma

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. Patients may report dark urine or light, pale stools. Many persons have no risk factors; however, those with a history of cirrhosis, sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B or C, liver fluke infection, and ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk. Diagnosis occurs through imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, which may disclose a variety of findings from bile duct wall thickening, a focal mass, or only dilation of bile ducts proximal to the presumed lesion location. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows for the potential direct visualization of the lesion location, bile duct scrapings or biopsy for definitive diagnosis, and stenting of any associated occlusion. Laboratory analysis typically discloses obstructive (direct) hyperbilirubinemia and increased alkaline phosphatase activity. Treatment includes surgical resection and chemotherapy; however, the condition is often late-stage or terminal at the time of diagnosis. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration (Choice A) is sometimes increased in cholangiocarcinoma; however, it is nonspecific and is also increased in colorectal carcinoma along with other various malignancies. It may be followed during treatment to assess treatment response but does not have a specific role in diagnosis. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) (Choice C) evaluates the patency of the hepatobiliary tree and gallbladder. It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. Liver biopsy (Choice D) is useful in the diagnosis of conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, though cholangiocarcinoma is generally small and confined to the biliary tree. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
7. A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a lesion on the left ear for 2 years . The lesion has gradually enlarged and ulcerated and occasionally bleeds with minor trauma .
The patient worked in construction for 40 years . The lesion is shown . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin neoplasm. It typically presents as a slow-growing, pink, waxy skin lesion with telangiectasias, central ulceration, or rolled borders that occurs in sun-exposed areas of the body, especially the face. It can also appear as a nonhealing ulcer. It can be locally invasive but is unlikely to metastasize. Treatment requires excisional biopsy with negative margins, and if locally infiltrative or involving sensitive facial structures, may require Mohs surgery for appropriate resection.

distractor_explanations.A: Actinic keratosis is a premalignant lesion that may progress to squamous cell carcinoma. They present as chronic rough, scaly patches of skin in areas of prolonged sun exposure (e.g., face, ears, hands).
distractor_explanations.C: Keratoacanthoma refers to a low-grade tumor that arises from pilosebaceous units and is thought to be related to or a variant of squamous cell carcinoma. They typically regress spontaneously, though they have the ability to invade and metastasize in rare cases. They appear as a papule with a central keratin plug, and generally expand rapidly over weeks.
distractor_explanations.D: Melanoma is likely to be present when a skin lesion demonstrates asymmetry, irregular-appearing borders, variable coloration, a diameter greater than 6 mm, and rapid evolution in characteristics. Malignant melanoma has the ability to rapidly invade and metastasize, which carries a poor prognosis when diagnosed late. Traumatic ulcer (Choice E) presents as a chronic, nonhealing wound in the setting of an injury. They are more common in persons with diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, and connective tissue disease. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 8 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
8. An 82-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because she has refused to eat because of a 2-day history of severe abdominal pain. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin . Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F),
pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 110/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation . Serum studies show:
Na • 138 mEq/L
K+ 4 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
HCO 20 mEq/L
3
Glucose 202 mg/dl
A CT scan of the abdomen shows thickening of the wall of the small bowel. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

vignette.presentation:
9. A 36-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus has fever and flank pain. Her temperature is 39°C (102 .2°F) . Gram stain of the urinary sediment shows many segmented neutrophils and gram-negative bacilli. Leukocyte count
is 27,000/mm 3 with 80% segmented neutrophils and 5% bands . Urine culture is positive for Escherichia coli . Ampicillin and gentamicin are administered intravenously . Ten days later, she continues to be febrile . Which of the
following is the most likely cause?

question_stem: the most likely cause?

choices.text: Natural course of E. coli pyelonephritis in a diabetic patient

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. vignette.presentation:
10. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision . She was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has severe abdominal pain. Her temperature is
36.5°C (97.7 °F) , pulse is 92/min , respirations are 13/min , and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. There is an abrasion over the right flank . The abdomen is nondistended with severe right upper quadrant tenderness . The
remainder of the examination , including pelvic and rectal examination , shows no abnormalities . Her hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dl . There is gross hematuria . A pelvic x-ray shows no abnormalities . Which of the following
is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Excessive intake of calcium and vitamin D

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) in the setting of hemodynamic stability is best evaluated using a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. BAT is commonly associated with injury involving the liver, spleen, and kidneys, and can include hematomas, contusions, lacerations, and in severe cases, devascularization and uncontrolled hemorrhage. Hematuria is highly suggestive of renal or retroperitoneal bleeding or hematoma. In contrast to stable BAT, hemodynamically unstable BAT is evaluated first with focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) followed by an exploratory laparotomy if positive, whereas stable BAT permits time for more thorough evaluation and the additional detail offered in a CT scan. Patients should also receive intravenous fluids, pain control, and supportive care as needed. There should be close monitoring of the patient's hemodynamics, as decompensation may occur rapidly if bleeding is present or continues unabated.

distractor_explanations.A: Measurement of serum creatinine concentration has a role in the evaluation of renal function following BAT but would not have an immediate role in the evaluation of a traumatic renal injury until such an injury is identified on a CT scan.
distractor_explanations.C: Cystography and cystoscopy (Choice E) have roles in the workup of hematuria when a bladder source is suspected. Retrograde urethrography (Choice D) permits evaluation of the urethra as a source of hematuria. However, in undifferentiated cases of BAT, a CT scan permits evaluation of the liver, spleen, kidneys, ureters, retroperitoneum, bladder, bony pelvis, and prostate, and should precede dedicated bladder or urethral imaging. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice F) is the correct choice in the management of unstable BAT, as it permits the control of hemorrhage and the repair of identified injuries. In stable cases, imaging precedes surgical intervention. r " , r-- r , 'I 11 . A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 6-day history of right flank pain that radiates to her right groin . She is otherwise asymptomatic . She has a 6-year history of Crohn disease and has undergone three resections of the small bowel , mostly involving the distal ileum , as well as resection of the right colon . Current medications include mesalamine , folic acid , and a daily multivitamin . Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F) , pulse is 100/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a well-healed surgical scar at the midline and mild tenderness of the right flank . A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a calculus in the middle of the right ureter. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating mechanism of this patient's current condition? A) Excessive intake of calcium and vitamin D B) Hyperparathyroidism C) Increased absorption of oxalate D) Increased secretion of cystine E) Increased secretion of uric acid Correct Answer: C. Nephrolithiasis or ureterolithiasis describes the formation of calculi within the urinary collecting system, otherwise known as kidney or ureteral calculi. Calcium oxalate calculi are the most common type (making up generally 80% of all urinary tract calculi), though calcium phosphate, struvite, uric acid, and proteinaceous calculi (e.g., cystine) are also seen. Crohn disease is a common risk factor for oxalate calculi. It results in increased gastrointestinal absorption of oxalates, leading to an increased serum concentration and increased urinary excretion. When paired with a calcium counterion, oxalates precipitate in the urine and may lead to calculi formation. Symptoms of kidney or ureteral calculi include colicky flank pain radiating to the groin, gross hematuria, and difficulty voiding. Complications include obstructive hydronephrosis, post-renal azotemia, and superimposed infection such as pyelonephritis. Diagnosis is through noncontrast CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Treatment varies depending on the size, location, and complicating features. Small, uncomplicated calculi often pass without intervention, whereas large, obstructing, or infected calculi may require antibiotics, surgical removal, ureteral stenting, or percutaneous nephrostomy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Excessive intake of calcium and vitamin D (Choice A) can promote the development of urinary tract calculi as calcium is frequently the precipitant counterion to oxalate in urine. The amount of calcium absorbed from the patient's use of a daily multivitamin would be unlikely to supply a sufficient concentration to cause hypercalcemia.
distractor_explanations.D: Increased secretion of cystine is a potential mechanism for nephrolithiasis and is generally hereditary. The mechanism relates to impaired cystine resorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, which results in cystinuria. Cystine is poorly soluble and precipitates easily into calculi. The condition generally presents in childhood and would be unlikely to manifest initially in an adult patient with known Crohn disease. Increased secretion of uric acid (Choice E) occurs most commonly in states of decreased urine volume and dry climates; increased pH also promotes uric acid precipitation. Urate calculi are associated with hyperuricemia (e.g., gout) and are also common in cases of increased cell turnover (e.g., tumor lysis syndrome). r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
12. A hospitalized 67-year-old man has chest pain 3 days after undergoing a left colectomy for adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon . He is diaphoretic . His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min and regular , respirations
are 16/min , and blood pressure is 95/75 mm Hg. The skin is cool. Crackles are heard halfway up the lung bases . Cardiac examination shows no murmurs or gallops . An ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads 11 , 111, and aVF.
Which of the following is the most likely finding on pulmonary artery catheterization?
Pulmonary Capillary Systemic
Cardiac Output Wedge Pressure Vascular Resistance

question_stem:
the most likely finding on pulmonary artery catheterization?
Pulmonary Capillary Systemic
Cardiac Output Wedge Pressure Vascular Resistance

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myocardial infarction classically presents with chest pain radiating to the arm or jaw and shortness of breath, often with diaphoresis on examination. Vital signs may show hypertension or hypotension depending on cardiac function. If left heart failure ensues, signs and symptoms of pulmonary edema such as shortness of breath, cough, tachypnea, hypoxia, and crackles may be present. If right heart failure occurs, peripheral edema, hepatic congestion, ascites, jugular venous distention, and hypotension may be present. ST-segment elevations in leads 11, Ill, and a VF suggest an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which classically occurs from occlusion of the right coronary artery. Cardiogenic shock is a potential complication. In cardiogenic shock, there is severe dysfunction of the cardiac myocytes, resulting in markedly decreased contractility. Pulmonary artery catheterization typically demonstrates decreased cardiac output and increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure because of the underlying systolic cardiac dysfunction. Systemic vascular resistance is commonly increased as a physiologic attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure in the setting of reduced cardiac output and peripheral perfusion.

distractor_explanations.H: Normal values reflect typical physiology without an associated insult and would not be expected in a case of cardiogenic shock from myocardial infarction. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 13 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
13. A previously healthy 6-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of fever and progressive left hip pain. She has refused to bear weight on her left leg since awakening 4 hours ago . There is no history of
trauma . She is now lying on the stretcher with her left leg abducted and externally rotated . Her temperature is 39.1° C (102.4 °F), pulse is 130/min , respirations are 24/min , and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. On examination ,
she resists any motion of the left lower extremity . There is warmth over the left hip but no erythema or swelling . Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 70 mm/h . Arthrocentesis of the left hip yields cloudy fluid ; joint fluid analysis
shows an erythrocyte count of 10 ,000/mm 3 and leukocyte count of 196,000/mm 3 Results of culture of the synovial fluid are pending . X-rays of the pelvis and left lower extremity show no abnormalities . In addition to intravenous
antibiotic therapy , which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Daily needle aspiration of the hip until her symptoms resolve

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Septic arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and presents with pain, inability to bear weight, reduced range of motion, fever, chills, nausea, myalgias, arthralgias, and fatigue. Vital signs may disclose a fever, tachycardia, or hypotension if it is complicated by bacteremia or sepsis. Physical examination typically discloses tenderness to palpation of the affected joint, a limited range of motion, pain with range of motion, joint effusion, and overlying cutaneous erythema. Routes of infection include direct inoculation, spread from an adjacent infection such as osteomyelitis, or hematogenous seeding. Diagnosis is through physical examination plus arthrocentesis, which classically discloses a neutrophilic-predominant exudate with a leukocyte count greater than 50,000/mm 3 Organisms are often seen on Gram stain and are detected by • culture. Treatment includes intravenous antibiotics plus emergent surgical incision and drainage to prevent complications including articular erosion, fibrous ankylosis, loss of the ability to ambulate, and the potential for sepsis and even death if severe.

distractor_explanations.A: Aspirin therapy is appropriate for cases of musculoskeletal pain or inflammatory arthritis but is generally never appropriate for use in a child outside of mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease) because of the risk for Reye syndrome. It does not have a defined role in the management of septic arthritis. Colchicine therapy (Choice B) is appropriate for inflammatory arthritis and is classically used in the treatment of gout. It inhibits microtubule formation which prevents white blood cell translocation into the joint, limiting inflammation and resultant arthropathy. Prednisone therapy (Choice C) is used primarily for inflammatory arthritis and has a role in the management of rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus-associated arthritis, and seronegative spondyloarthropathies. Daily needle aspiration of the hip until her symptoms resolve (Choice D) would not appropriately resolve the infection. Emergent surgical incision and drainage followed by antibiotics are required to prevent joint complications and potential sepsis. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
14. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral breast enlargement for 6 months . He takes no medications and does not drink alcohol. Examination shows tender gynecomastia bilaterally and a small nodule on
the left testicle . Liver function tests and serum 13-hCG concentration are within the reference range . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia G) Penile cancer
Herpes simplex I) Primary gonadal failure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Leydig cell tumors arise from the interstitial cells of the testicle, specifically the Leydig cell, which physiologically produces sex hormones in response to stimulus from luteinizing hormone. Generally, Leydig cells secrete androgens in men; however, they can also secrete estrogens, especially in states of dysregulation (e.g., malignancy). In young boys, such upregulation of androgens presents with precocious puberty, while in women it presents with masculinization (e.g., amenorrhea, hirsutism, temporal balding, acne, deepening of the voice, clitoromegaly). Gynecomastia and a testicular nodule in a postpubertal, otherwise healthy male is suggestive of a functional estrogen secreting Leydig cell tumor. Diagnosis requires testicular ultrasonography, followed by orchiectomy and histologic evaluation.

vignette.presentation:
15. Thirty minutes after undergoing a radical gastrectomy for gastric carcinoma , a 67-year-old woman has an oxygen saturation of 84% . She was extubated in the operating room and is currently receiving 6 L/min of oxygen via
nasal cannula and intravenous morphine for pain . She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years and has mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min and regular,
respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention . Breath sounds are decreased at the bases . Cardiac examination shows no murmurs or gallops . A portable x-ray of the chest
shows moderate elevation of both diaphragms ; no other abnormalities are noted . Arterial blood gas analysis shows :
7.26
73 mm Hg
56 mm Hg
29 mEq/L
Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's respiratory insufficiency?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of this patient's respiratory insufficiency?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Following thoracic or abdominal surgery, breathing often creates discomfort for patients by exacerbating postoperative pain. As a result, patients often splint their breathing, resulting in bradypnea and low tidal volume, which will decrease alveolar minute ventilation leading to the development of hypoxemia and acute respiratory acidosis. Underlying respiratory impairment (e.g., history of smoking, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) may further exacerbate hypoventilation. Vital signs may disclose bradypnea and low arterial oxygen saturation. Physical examination will demonstrate diminished respiratory effort, often with reduced breath sounds at the lung bases because of atelectasis and inadequate diaphragmatic excursion. Arterial blood gas analysis may disclose an acidic pH with increases in both Pco and HCO along with low arterial oxygen -, 2 3 tension. Hypoxemia will improve with the administration of supplemental oxygen, whereas hypercapnia will persist until the resolution of ventilatory insufficiency. Pain control, incentive spirometry, and respiratory therapy with lung expansion maneuvers are key initial steps in management.

distractor_explanations.B: Decreased pulmonary blood flow may be noted in cases of pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension, right-sided heart failure, or the presence of a right-to-left shunt. Increased alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (Choice C) occurs in cases of right-to-left shunt, ventilation-perfusion mismatch, diffusion abnormality, and dead space; the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient is normal in cases of isolated alveolar hypoventilation. Increased metabolic demands (Choice D) generally result in increased minute ventilation. The respiratory system compensates for the increased production of carbon dioxide and organic acids through increased ventilation. Increased physiologic dead space (Choice E) may occur in cases where the alveolar membrane no longer functions correctly or is not appropriately perfused (e.g., pulmonary embolism). This results in the presence of air within an alveolus for which gas exchange does not occur. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 16 of 50

vignette.presentation:
16. A previously healthy 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friend 1 hour after being thrown from his bicycle and striking his head on a tree . He was not wearing a helmet. He lost consciousness at the
scene for less than 1 minute and then was able to stand and walk with his bicycle back to his friend's car. He fell asleep in the back seat of the car and could not be aroused when they arrived home 30 minutes later. His
temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 45/min , respirations are 5/min , and blood pressure is 180/90 mm Hg. The left pupil is 6 mm and unreactive , and the right pupil is 4 mm and reactive . Examination shows intact
oculocephalic and corneal reflexes . He withdraws the left upper and lower extremities to noxious stimuli but does not open his eyes or speak . The right upper extremity is flexed on the chest , and the right lower extremity is
rigidly extended . CT scans of the head without contrast are shown . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the brain with contrast

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cholangiocarcinoma, a malignancy of the bile ducts, characteristically presents late in its course with signs of biliary tree obstruction, including abdominal discomfort, weight loss, nausea, jaundice, and pruritus. Patients may report dark urine or light, pale stools. Many persons have no risk factors; however, those with a history of cirrhosis, sclerosing cholangitis, hepatitis B or C, liver fluke infection, and ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk. Diagnosis occurs through imaging of the abdomen with CT scan or MRI, which may disclose a variety of findings from bile duct wall thickening, a focal mass, or only dilation of bile ducts proximal to the presumed lesion location. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) allows for the potential direct visualization of the lesion location, bile duct scrapings or biopsy for definitive diagnosis, and stenting of any associated occlusion. Laboratory analysis typically discloses obstructive (direct) hyperbilirubinemia and increased alkaline phosphatase activity. Treatment includes surgical resection and chemotherapy; however, the condition is often late-stage or terminal at the time of diagnosis. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Measurement of serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) concentration (Choice A) is sometimes increased in cholangiocarcinoma; however, it is nonspecific and is also increased in colorectal carcinoma along with other various malignancies. It may be followed during treatment to assess treatment response but does not have a specific role in diagnosis. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) (Choice C) evaluates the patency of the hepatobiliary tree and gallbladder. It is useful in cases of suspected acute cholecystitis, choledocholithiasis, or biliary obstruction with indeterminate ultrasonography findings. It does not permit tissue sampling such as biopsy or therapeutic interventions such as stenting. Liver biopsy (Choice D) is useful in the diagnosis of conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, though cholangiocarcinoma is generally small and confined to the biliary tree. These features may result in false negative liver biopsy results and should prompt targeted sampling via ERCP. Exploratory laparotomy (Choice E) involves the surgical evaluation of the peritoneal cavity and is commonly employed in the diagnosis and management of abdominal trauma, bowel obstruction, peritonitis, and undifferentiated cases of an acute abdomen. It does not have an immediate role in the diagnosis or management of cholangiocarcinoma. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
17. A 2-day-old male newborn has a 6-hour history of shortness of breath and blue lips and extremities . He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He appears cyanotic . His pulse is 164/min ,
respirations are 68/min , and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 75% and increases to 78% with administration of 100% oxygen by face mask . Diffuse crackles are heard in both lung fields . S is
2
loud; no murmur is heard . The liver edge is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin . A chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and moderate pulmonary congestion . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital heart disease is often subdivided into cyanotic and noncyanotic types depending on the direction of blood shunting. Structural heart defects that result in flow of deoxygenated blood from the pulmonary to systemic circulations (a right-to-left shunt) classically present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, hypoxia, tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension generally within 1 to 7 days after birth. Common culprit lesions include truncus arteriosus, transposition of the great vessels, tricuspid atresia, tetralogy of Fallo!, and total anomalous pulmonary venous return. These lesions require the concomitant presence of a left-to-right shunt (patent ductus arteriosus) to allow for a degree of blood oxygenation. Without a left-to-right shunt, a complete absence of oxygenation can occur because of the separated circulatory systems, which is incompatible with life. In cases of a suspected congenital cyanotic heart defect, intravenous prostaglandin should be started, which maintains a patent ductus arteriosus. Administration of indomethacin or similar nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medications should be avoided, as these will result in closure of the ductus arteriosus. Echocardiography is required to determine the structural defects to confirm the right-to-left shunt and to assist in operative planning.

distractor_explanations.B: CT scan of the chest can provide structural but only limited functional information about the heart, whereas an echocardiography permits analysis of structural defects, pressure, velocity, and flow of blood which is important in understanding the hemodynamics associated with structural heart disease. Administration of indomethacin (Choice C) would result in closure of the ductus arteriosus and could worsen the degree of right-to-left shunting with resultant severe hypoxia. Administration of surfactant (Choice D) may have an adjunct role in certain cases of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome because of the inadequate production of surfactant in the setting of premature birth; however, the pulmonary function in congenital heart disease is often not affected. Cardiac catheterization (Choice E) may be necessary to further assist in evaluation of the heart anatomy and intracardiac pressures, but it is not the best next step, as echocardiography is often sufficient and does not require an invasive procedure. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
18. A previously healthy 27-year-old primigravid woman at 28 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 2 days after the onset of constant right upper abdominal pain . Her symptoms have worsened over the past 12 hours .
During this period , she also has had decreased appetite , nausea and vomiting , and decreased fetal movement. She has had no contractions , vaginal bleeding , abnormal vaginal discharge , or change in bowel movements . Her
temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F), pulse is 95/min , and blood pressure is 138/70 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation . Heart sounds are normal. Examination shows a soft abdomen and tenderness in the right upper
quadrant with voluntary guarding and no rebound . Bowel sounds are normal. Fundal height is 28 cm . Laboratory studies show :
Hemoglobin 12 g/dL
Leukocyte count 14,000/mm 3
Platelet count 140,000/mm 3
Prothrombin time 12 sec (INR=1 .06)
Serum
Na + 142 mEq/L
K+
4.5 mEq/L
Cl · 104 mEq/L
Total bilirubin 1.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 268 U/L
AST 40 U/L
ALT 44 U/L
Urine
Glucose negative
Protein trace
Ketones 2+
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute cholecystitis occurs secondary to obstruction of the cystic duct from a lodged gallstone, which results in subsequent inflammation of the gallbladder wall. It classically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant, often in a patient with a history of gallstones. It is occasionally preceded by symptoms of biliary colic. It is more commonly seen in women with obesity in their 40s to 50s, especially those having a history of multi parity. Risk factors include gallstones, biliary sludge, or conditions that slow or delay gastric emptying or reduce contractility of the gallbladder such as pregnancy or total parenteral nutrition. Diagnosis is through clinical history, physical examination, and ultrasonography, which may disclose pericholecystic fluid, a dilated gallbladder, gallbladder wall thickening and hyperemia, the presence of gallstones, and a sonographic Murphy sign (pain with compression directly over the gallbladder). Treatment involves surgical resection of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy). lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. Abruptio placentae (Choice A) presents with vaginal bleeding, severe uterine pain, and tetanic contractions, typically in the third trimester. It commonly results from lower abdominal trauma, smoking, or cocaine use. Acute appendicitis (Choice B) presents with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant, fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and leukocytosis. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Prothrombin time 12 sec {INR=1 .06) Serum Na + 142 mEq/L K + 4.5 mEq/L cI- 104 mEq/L TotaI bilirubin 1.8 mg/dl Alkaline phosphatase 268 U/L AST 40 U/L ALT 44 U/L Urine Glucose negative Protein trace Ketones 2+ Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Abruptio placentae B) Acute appendicitis C) Acute cholecystitis D) Acute fatty liver of pregnancy E) Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome F) Severe preeclampsia Correct Answer: C. Acute cholecystitis occurs secondary to obstruction of the cystic duct from a lodged gallstone, which results in subsequent inflammation of the gallbladder wall. It classically presents with fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant, often in a patient with a history of gallstones. It is occasionally preceded by symptoms of biliary colic. It is more commonly seen in women with obesity in their 40s to 50s, especially those having a history of multi parity. Risk factors include gallstones, biliary sludge, or conditions that slow or delay gastric emptying or reduce contractility of the gallbladder such as pregnancy or total parenteral nutrition. Diagnosis is through clinical history, physical examination, and ultrasonography, which may disclose pericholecystic fluid, a dilated gallbladder, gallbladder wall thickening and hyperemia, the presence of gallstones, and a sonographic Murphy sign (pain with compression directly over the gallbladder). Treatment involves surgical resection of the gallbladder {cholecystectomy). lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. Abruptio placentae {Choice A) presents with vaginal bleeding, severe uterine pain, and tetanic contractions, typically in the third trimester. It commonly results from lower abdominal trauma, smoking, or cocaine use. Acute appendicitis {Choice B) presents with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant, fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and leukocytosis. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy {Choice D) presents with insidious right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and jaundice. In severe cases, liver function testing may disclose transaminitis, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, hypoalbuminemia, and coagulopathy. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome {Choice E) describes perihepatic inflammation secondary to pelvic inflammatory disease, often because of Neisseria or Chlamydia species. It does not directly affect the gallbladder. Severe preeclampsia {Choice F) presents with multisystem organ failure and is marked by severe hypertension, headaches, retinopathy, proteinuria, end-stage kidney disease, and liver failure. It may also present with hemolysis and thrombocytopenia. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 19 of 50

vignette.presentation:
19. A previously healthy 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue . He reports a decrease in exercise tolerance and in overall energy during this period .
He has not had chest pain or shortness of breath . He takes no medications and has no known allergies . His father and paternal uncle underwent splenectomy in their 20s ; the patient is
unsure of the reason for these procedures . The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs . He consumes two mixed drinks of gin and tonic most weekends . He appears
comfortable and is not in distress . He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m 2 His pulse is 90/min , and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. The conjunctivae are
•
pale. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin . A blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in management?

vignette.presentation:
20. A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being rescued from a house fire . Firefighters found him unconscious in his bed; the bedroom was full of smoke . The firefighters and paramedics state that the
patient probably fell asleep while smoking in bed. On arrival , he does not respond to verbal stimuli and has cough productive of carbonaceous sputum . His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) , pulse is 120/min , respirations are 30/min
and labored , and blood pressure is 98/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 50% oxygen by face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 93% . Examination shows second degree burns over the face and upper extremities . There is
marked facial edema , and the eyebrows are singed . On pulmonary examination , air movement is poor. Stridor and wheezes are heard over the lung bases bilaterally . The patient's carboxyhemoglobin concentration is 35% .
Arterial blood gas analysis on 50% oxygen by face mask shows :
pH 7.25
Pco 65 mm Hg
2
Po 45 mm Hg
2
After endotracheal intubation and administration of 100% oxygen, this patient should receive fluid resuscitation with which of the following during the next 12 hours?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Ovarian cancer classically presents late in the course and is often metastatic and invasive at the time of discovery. Presenting features are often nonspecific and may include weight loss, abdominal discomfort or distention, ascites, and gastrointestinal symptoms including early satiety, bloating, nausea, cramping, and bowel obstruction. Bowel obstruction can occur because of locally invasive disease or because of peritoneal carcinomatosis, which is often a common presenting diagnosis. Spread of the malignancy throughout the peritoneum results in bowel and omental implants, which on gross surgical examination is described as "caking." The resultant mechanical distortion, tethering, and compression of bowel leads to obstruction in a similar mechanism to postoperative adhesions and strictures. Any incidental ovarian enlargement or cyst in a woman over age 50 years should be investigated for malignancy with imaging and potentially biopsy. Ovarian cancer is also potentially hereditary, with an increased frequency of cases seen in women with mutations in BRCA 1/2 and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer. Treatment includes surgical resection and debulking plus chemotherapy. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to maximize survival.

distractor_explanations.A: Colloid and isotonic crystalloid solution is incorrect as colloids are generally not deficient in the setting of burns (e.g., albumin). The administration of isotonic crystalloids alone is the standard of care for resuscitative fluid administration as it provides the most direct intravascular benefit. Fresh frozen plasma (Choice B) is appropriate for use as a resuscitation fluid in cases of severe blood loss as part of a balanced resuscitation treatment plan. It is also used in reversing anticoagulation when prothrombin complex concentrates are not available. It does not have a primary role in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. Hypertonic crystalloid solution only (Choice C) is used in the management of acute hyponatremia with neurologic deficits and to reduce cerebral edema in cases of elevated intracranial pressure. It does not have a primary role in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. Packed red blood cells (Choice E) are used as a component of resuscitation in cases of hemorrhagic shock. Unless blood loss or severe anemia is also present, they are not used in the fluid resuscitation of patients with burns. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 21 . A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of increasingly severe abdominal cramps . She also has had a bloating feeling for 6 months . She has not had any operative procedures . Examination shows a nontender , distended , tympanitic abdomen with tinkles and peristaltic rushes on auscultation . There are no masses . Rectal examination shows no abnormalities . An x-ray of the abdomen is shown . After hydration and nasogastric suction , an exploratory laparotomy is performed . Two liters of serous fluid are drained from the abdomen . Peritoneal and bowel surfaces are studded with nodules . The omentum is thickened and "caked" with nodules of tumor , and there is thickening of the underside of the diaphragm . Both ovaries are markedly enlarged and appear abnormal. A frozen section of one of the nodules confirms a malignancy and the presence of psammoma bodies . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Colon cancer B) Endometrial cancer C) Gastric cancer D) Metastatic breast cancer E) Metastatic cervical cancer F) Ovarian cancer G) Pancreatic cancer Correct Answer: F. Ovarian cancer classically presents late in the course and is often metastatic and invasive at the time of discovery. Presenting features are often nonspecific and may include weight loss, abdominal discomfort or distention, ascites, and gastrointestinal symptoms including early satiety, bloating, nausea, cramping, and bowel obstruction. Bowel obstruction can occur because of locally invasive disease or because of peritoneal carcinomatosis, which is often a common presenting diagnosis. Spread of the malignancy throughout the peritoneum results in bowel and omental implants, which on gross surgical examination is described as "caking." The resultant mechanical distortion, tethering, and compression of bowel leads to obstruction in a similar mechanism to postoperative adhesions and strictures. Any incidental ovarian enlargement or cyst in a woman over age 50 years should be investigated for malignancy with imaging and potentially biopsy. Ovarian cancer is also potentially hereditary, with an increased frequency of cases seen in women with mutations in BRCA 1/2 and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer. Treatment includes surgical resection and debulking plus chemotherapy. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to maximize survival. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, and G. Colon cancer (Choice A) may present with symptoms of a bowel obstruction, especially if left-sided (descending colon). Classic symptoms of left-sided colon cancer include weight loss, tenesmus, constipation, narrow stools, and large bowel obstruction. Right-sided (ascending colon) lesions classically present with occult bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. Endometrial cancer (Choice B) classically arises in older women who have been chronically exposed to uninterrupted estrogen stimulation (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, using tamoxifen, using exogenous hormones). Any unexplained vaginal bleeding in a postmenopausal woman should be investigated, as endometrial carcinoma may be present. Gastric cancer (Choice C) classically presents with weight loss, early satiety, and melena in a patient with a history of smoking, peptic ulcer disease, chronic gastritis, or frequent consumption of nitrate-containing foods. Gastric outlet obstruction is a potential complication, which presents as nausea, left upper quadrant and epigastric discomfort, and nonbilious emesis containing partially digested food. Metastatic breast cancer (Choice D) most commonly spreads to the bone, lung, and brain, and would be less likely to present with omental and peritoneal metastases. Metastatic cervical cancer (Choice E) often invades locally into the bladder or rectum and does not classically present with omental or peritoneal metastasis.
